## Evidence & Reasoning Sentence Starters

Use these in Socratic Seminar, think-pair-share, and group inquiry activities. The goal is not fancy wording—it's clear scientific thinking.

<div class="card-grid">

<details class="collapsible-card">
<summary>Claim (what you think is true)</summary>
<div class="collapsible-card-content">
<ul>
<li>"A conservative interpretation is that..."</li>
<li>"The figure suggests that..."</li>
<li>"My current best claim is..."</li>
</ul>
</div>
</details>

<details class="collapsible-card">
<summary>Evidence (what you're pointing to)</summary>
<div class="collapsible-card-content">
<ul>
<li>"I'm basing that on ___ (axis/line/value/quote)..."</li>
<li>"In the region where ___, the trend shows..."</li>
<li>"The key detail is ___, which indicates..."</li>
</ul>
</div>
</details>

<details class="collapsible-card">
<summary>Reasoning (why the evidence supports the claim)</summary>
<div class="collapsible-card-content">
<ul>
<li>"That supports the claim because..."</li>
<li>"If ___ increases, then ___ should change because..."</li>
<li>"The physical story is: ___ → ___ → ___."</li>
</ul>
</div>
</details>

<details class="collapsible-card">
<summary>Assumptions (what must be true)</summary>
<div class="collapsible-card-content">
<ul>
<li>"This depends on the assumption that..."</li>
<li>"We're implicitly assuming ___ (calibration / geometry / equilibrium / negligible dust)..."</li>
<li>"If that assumption fails, the conclusion could change by..."</li>
</ul>
</div>
</details>

<details class="collapsible-card">
<summary>Alternative explanations (how to avoid tunnel vision)</summary>
<div class="collapsible-card-content">
<ul>
<li>"Another explanation consistent with the data is..."</li>
<li>"A competing model would predict..."</li>
<li>"These interpretations differ mainly in the assumption that..."</li>
</ul>
</div>
</details>

<details class="collapsible-card">
<summary>Uncertainty (allowed; vagueness is not)</summary>
<div class="collapsible-card-content">
<ul>
<li>"I'm about __% confident because..."</li>
<li>"The biggest uncertainty is..."</li>
<li>"I'm unsure whether ___ or ___, because the data don't constrain..."</li>
</ul>
</div>
</details>

<details class="collapsible-card">
<summary>Discriminating tests (what would we measure next?)</summary>
<div class="collapsible-card-content">
<ul>
<li>"A measurement that would distinguish these is..."</li>
<li>"If we observe ___, it would support model A; if we observe ___, it would support model B."</li>
<li>"The next-best observation would be ___ because it reduces the degeneracy between..."</li>
</ul>
</div>
</details>

<details class="collapsible-card">
<summary>Building on others (collaboration moves)</summary>
<div class="collapsible-card-content">
<ul>
<li>"I want to build on what ___ said by adding..."</li>
<li>"I agree with ___ under the condition that..."</li>
<li>"I interpret that differently because the evidence suggests..."</li>
</ul>
</div>
</details>

</div>

## Common Astronomy Inference Pitfalls

Astronomy is inference under constraints. These pitfalls are *normal*—the goal is to notice them early and build guardrails.

Use this sheet during problem-solving and seminar.

<div class="card-grid">

<details class="collapsible-card">
<summary>1. Mixing up what's measured vs what's inferred</summary>
<div class="collapsible-card-content">
<p><strong>Guardrail:</strong> Write "Observable:" and "Inference:" separately.</p>
<p>Example: flux is measured; distance is inferred using a model.</p>
</div>
</details>

<details class="collapsible-card">
<summary>2. Confusing brightness with luminosity</summary>
<div class="collapsible-card-content">
<ul>
<li><strong>Brightness (flux)</strong> depends on distance.</li>
<li><strong>Luminosity</strong> is intrinsic power output.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Guardrail:</strong> Ask: "Is this property distance-dependent?"</p>
</div>
</details>

<details class="collapsible-card">
<summary>3. Treating a model assumption as a fact</summary>
<div class="collapsible-card-content">
<p>Examples: circular orbits, equilibrium, "standard candle," negligible dust.</p>
<p><strong>Guardrail:</strong> Say: "This conclusion holds <em>if</em> ____."</p>
</div>
</details>

<details class="collapsible-card">
<summary>4. Over-claiming (data show X → therefore theory Y is true)</summary>
<div class="collapsible-card-content">
<p>Data usually constrain a <em>family</em> of models.</p>
<p><strong>Guardrail:</strong> Ask: "What else could explain this pattern?"</p>
</div>
</details>

<details class="collapsible-card">
<summary>5. Ignoring selection effects ("what got into the dataset?")</summary>
<div class="collapsible-card-content">
<p>What you observe is shaped by detection limits and survey design.</p>
<p><strong>Guardrail:</strong> Ask: "What might be missing, and why?"</p>
</div>
</details>

<details class="collapsible-card">
<summary>6. Forgetting units or axis scaling (especially log axes)</summary>
<div class="collapsible-card-content">
<p>A straight line on a log plot means something different than on a linear plot.</p>
<p><strong>Guardrail:</strong> Always write the units and identify linear vs log.</p>
</div>
</details>

<details class="collapsible-card">
<summary>7. Confusing correlation with causation</summary>
<div class="collapsible-card-content">
<p>Two quantities can vary together due to a third variable or measurement bias.</p>
<p><strong>Guardrail:</strong> Ask: "What mechanism connects them? What would break the trend?"</p>
</div>
</details>

<details class="collapsible-card">
<summary>8. Treating uncertainty as a footnote</summary>
<div class="collapsible-card-content">
<p>Uncertainty is part of the claim.</p>
<p><strong>Guardrail:</strong> Try: "I'm ~__% confident because..." and name your biggest uncertainty.</p>
</div>
</details>

<details class="collapsible-card">
<summary>9. Single-figure tunnel vision</summary>
<div class="collapsible-card-content">
<p>A great plot can still be misleading without context (calibration, sample, method).</p>
<p><strong>Guardrail:</strong> Ask: "What information is missing that could change interpretation?"</p>
</div>
</details>

</div>

::: {.callout-tip}
## The most scientific question you can ask

**"What observation would discriminate between these explanations?"**
:::
